Detailed Description

This provides a number of utilities for getting input information.

This is useful for quickly and easily getting common input information.

Member Function Documentation

void phys::InputQueryTool::GatherEvents ( bool  ClearEventsFromEventMgr = false  ) 

This gathers any user-input/event data that might be queryed.

This should be called periodcally (ideally in the post user input callback) to allow this to gather data from the phys::World 's event manager. When called this will drop prior event data and any relevant queries will come from this new data. At the caller's discretion this method can properly delete any events pulled from the event manager.

This runs in linear time relative to the events in the event manager. This will usually be a trivial amount if this is run each iteration and excess events are removed (either by this method or some other form of event cleanup)

Parameters:
ClearEventsFromEventMgr If set to true, This method will properly remove any events it pulls from the event manager.

Todo:
Add support for joysticks events to InputQueryTool

MetaCode::ButtonState phys::InputQueryTool::GetMouseButtonState ( short unsigned int  MouseButton  ) 

Gets the button state of the provided mouse button ID.

Parameters:
MouseButton The mouse button ID(up to 16) you wish to query.

Far from all mice have 16 buttons, be sure you know how many buttons the mouse has As this function doesn't perform that check.

Returns:
Returns a button state enum representing the button state.

Vector2 phys::InputQueryTool::GetMouseCoordinates (  ) 

This gets a vector2 containing both X and Y coordinates of the mouse.

If precision is important then you should use the individual coordinate fetching functions instead.

Returns:
This returns a Vector2 containing Reals to represent both mouse coordinates.

Definition at line 62 of file inputquerytool.cpp.

Vector2 phys::InputQueryTool::GetMousePrevFrameOffset (  ) 

This gets the offset location of the mouse since the previous frame.

This Vector2 is only accurate if this class gathers events every frame. Avoid calling this function otherwise.

Returns:
This returns a vector2 that stores how the mouse has moved since the previous frame.

Definition at line 59 of file inputquerytool.cpp.

bool phys::InputQueryTool::IsKeyboardButtonPushed ( MetaCode::InputCode  KeyboardButton  ) 

Returns whether a specific KEyboard button is pushed.

This runs in constant time and returns a true is the requested mouse button is pressed. Buttons that are being pressed are considered pressed, and buttons that are being lifted are considered unpressed.

Parameters:
KeyboardButton This is the button that is being checked.
Returns:
This returns a bool which is set to true if the requested button is pressed or held down, and false otherwise.

Definition at line 75 of file inputquerytool.cpp.

bool phys::InputQueryTool::IsMouseButtonPushed ( short unsigned int  MouseButton  ) 

Returns whether a specific Mouse button is pushed.

This runs in constant time and returns a true is the requested mouse button is pressed. Buttons that are being pressed are considered pressed, and buttons that are being lifted are considered unpressed. This only supports the first 16 mouse buttons at this point (numbered 0 to 15)

Parameters:
MouseButton This is the mouse button that is being checked
Exceptions:
Unsupported mouse button access through InputQueryTool This is thrown whenever a mouse button is requested that is beyond the limit that is supported. Currently this limit is 16
Returns:
This returns a bool which is set to true if the requested button is pressed or held down, and false otherwise.
